title: Tropical Storm Imelda: more than 1,000 rescued as floodwaters swamp Texas
text:
Crews have rescued more than 1,000 people in the Houston area because of rising waters caused by the remnants of Tropical Depression Imelda.

Texas’s governor, Greg Abbott, has declared 13 counties disaster areas after heavy rain and flooding from the remnants of the tropical storm swamped parts of south-east Texas.

Hundreds of flights were canceled or delayed at George Bush intercontinental airport in Houston. The National Weather Service said “life-threatening amounts of rainfall” had fallen with more expected through Thursday.

WBRZ News (@WBRZ) VIDEO: Major flooding in east Texas due to Imelda https://t.co/aHeqxX61Qc pic.twitter.com/51tvL64f7h

The Harris county judge, Lina Hidalgo, said the rescues have happened in the eastern part of the county because of flooding. A flash flood emergency for the area would remain in effect until 3pm Thursday.

Officials are urging the public to stay off the roads.

The Harris county sheriff, Ed Gonzalez, said among those rescued were nine children and employees from a daycare center that had taken on water in Aldine, about 10 miles (16 kilometers) north of Houston.

Courtney Fischer (@CourtneyABC13) Incredible. These cars and SUVs look like toys, tossed around. This is just awful. #abc13 #Winnie https://t.co/wMfRfIa3w7 pic.twitter.com/UCwbs8xCHm

The National Hurricane Center says the center of Imelda was located about 55 miles (90 kilometers) north of Houston as of 10am Thursday. The hurricane center says the storm system could cause isolated rainfall totals of up to 40 inches (100 centimeters) this week in parts of south-east Texas.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Don Dressler pulls his granddaughters Elsie and Jillian Deans on a kayak through floodwaters from Tropical Storm Imelda in Galveston, Texas. Photograph: Kelsey Walling/Associated Press

Abbott on Thursday announced the disaster declaration for Brazoria, Chambers, Galveston, Hardin, Harris, Jasper, Jefferson, Liberty, Matagorda, Montgomery, Newton, Orange and San Jacinto counties.

WBRZ News (@WBRZ) VIDEO: Major flooding in east Texas due to Imelda https://t.co/aHeqxX61Qc pic.twitter.com/51tvL64f7h

The National Weather Service said most of south-east Texas was under a flash flood watch through Friday morning.

The Chambers county sheriff, Brian Hawthorne, said emergency personnel completed more than 300 high-water rescues on Thursday in the town of Winnie, located 60 miles east of Houston. Hawthorne had no reports of anyone hurt.

Katherine Marchand (@KatherineMABC13) THIS IS CRAZY: Normally a 4-lane highway. Not today.



Everyone going southbound on 59 forced to form a single file line - the left shoulder is the only part that isn’t flooded!



Traffic crawling!



AVOID 59S NEAR NEW CANEY!!#Imelda #Texas #flooding https://t.co/UD7dvMlA5A pic.twitter.com/xoHdGkZg0w

A Texas department of transportation spokeswoman, Sarah Dupre, said officials did not know exactly how many people were stranded in their cars on Interstate 10, which was closed from Beaumont to Winnie. Dupre said the department was working with local law enforcement on a plan to get those people off the roadway.

Hawthorne said the sheriff’s office was focusing on high-water rescues in Winnie and neighboring Stowell.

Hawthorne says some residents were up on their roofs because of rising floodwaters.

NBC News (@NBCNews) WATCH: Video shows extent of severe flooding in Beaumont as Texas Game Wardens conduct water rescues in the area.



34 inches of rain have fallen in Beaumont in the past 24 hours.



Latest: https://t.co/UEdy4orpLC pic.twitter.com/TgYziUOpd7

Hawthorne told the Associated Press that the town “looks like a lake”. He said it was the worst storm-related flooding he had seen after going through hurricanes including Rita in 2005, Ike in 2008, and Harvey two years ago.

In Beaumont, police said on Twitter that they had had requests for more than 250 water rescues and 270 evacuations.
description: Rising waters caused by the remnants of a tropical depression have canceled flights and prompted rescues of more than 1,000 people
